column1: #Text=Polycrystalline pure phase of Sb2Si2Te6 was synthesized by ball milling and annealing processes.

#Text=High-purity Sb shots (99.9999%, American Elements), Si powders (99.999%, 5N Plus, Alfa Aesar), Te shots (99.999%, American Elements), and stearic acid (98.5%, Sigma Aldrich) were used as the starting materials.

#Text=Stoichiometric starting materials Sb (1.82625 g), Si (0.42128 g), Te (5.742 g), and stearic acid (5 mg) were loaded into a stainless-steel jar (50 mL) with 7 stainless-steel balls (diameter 10 mm).
#Text=Inside a glove box the jar was evacuated, N2-filled, and sealed.
#Text=The jar was then taken outside of the glove box and subjected to a planetary ball mill (PM 100, RETSCH) with a rotational speed of 450 rpm for 2 h.
#Text=The obtained powder sample (Figure S26) was taken in the glove box and loaded into 13 mm diameter silica tubes and then flame-sealed under a residual pressure of ∼10−4 Torr.
#Text=The tube was vertically placed in a box furnace, slowly heated to 823 K for 5 h, annealed at this temperature for 2 days, and finally cooled to room temperature naturally.
